description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals& Chemistry Daily Daily-- New study results on catalysis research have been published. According to news reporting originating from Tokyo, Japan, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated,“ Developing a novel ammonia synthesis process from N and H is of interest to the catalysis and hydrogen research...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals &
Chemistry Daily Daily \-- New study results on catalysis research have been
published. According to news reporting originating from Tokyo, Japan, by
NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Developing a novel ammonia synthesis
process from N [ [2] ] and H [ [2] ] is of interest to the catalysis and
hydrogen research communities. g-Alumina-supported nickel was determined
capable of serving as an efficient catalyst for ammonia synthesis using
nonthermal plasma under atmospheric pressure without heating. The catalytic
activity was almost unrelated to the crystal structure and the surface area of
the alumina carrier."

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Waseda
University: "The activity of Ni/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] was quantitatively
compared with that of Fe/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] and Ru/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] ,
which contained active metals for the conventional Haber-Bosch process. The
activity sequence was Ni/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] > Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] > Fe/Al [
[2] ] O [ [3] ] > no additive > Ru/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] , surprisingly
indicating that the loading of Fe and Ru decreased the activity of Al [ [2] ]
O [ [3] ]. The catalytic activity of Ni/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] was dependent on
the amount of loaded Ni, the calcination temperature, and the reaction time.
XRD, visual, and XPS observations of the catalysts before the plasma reaction
indicated the generation of NiO and NiAl [ [2] ] O [ [4] ] on Al [ [2] ] O [
[3] ] , the latter of which was generated upon high-temperature calcination.
The NiO species was readily reduced to Ni metal in the plasma reaction,
whereas the NiAl [ [2] ] O [ [4] ] species was difficult to reduce. The
catalytic behavior could be attributed to the production of fine Ni metal
particles that served as active sites."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The P [ [N2] ] /P [
[H2] ] ratio dependence and rate constants of formation and decomposition of
ammonia were finally determined for 5.0 wt % Ni/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] calcined
at 773 K. The ammonia yield was 6.3% at an applied voltage of 6.0 kV, a
residence time of reactant gases of 0.12 min, and P [ [H2] ] /P [ [N2 ] ] =
1."

For more information on this research see: Higher Activity of Ni/g-Al [ [2] ]
O [ [3] ] over Fe/g-Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] and Ru/g-Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] for
Catalytic Ammonia Synthesis in Nonthermal Atmospheric-Pressure Plasma of N [
[2] ] and H [ [2] ]. _Catalysts_ , 2020,10(590):590. (Catalysts -
<http://www.mdpi.com/journal/catalysts>). The publisher for Catalysts is MDPI
AG.

A free version of this journal article is available at
<https://doi.org/10.3390/catal10050590>.

Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting
Masakazu Iwamoto, Research Institute for Science and Engineering, Waseda
University, 3-4-1 Okubo, Sinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169-8555, Japan. Additional authors
for this research include Masataka Horikoshi, Ryu Hashimoto, Kaori Shimano,
Tomiko Sawaguchi, Harunobu Teduka, Masahiko Matsukata.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Catalysis Research Study Findings Have Been Published by Researchers at Waseda University (Higher Activity of Ni/g-Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] over Fe/g-Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] and Ru/g-Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] for Catalytic Ammonia Synthesis in ...): Chemicals and Chemistry - Catalysis Research
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals & Chemistry Daily Daily -- New study results on catalysis research have been published. According to news reporting originating from Tokyo, Japan, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “Developing a novel ammonia synthesis process from N [ [2] ] and H [ [2] ] is of interest to the catalysis and hydrogen research communities. g-Alumina-supported nickel was determined capable of serving as an efficient catalyst for ammonia synthesis using nonthermal plasma under atmospheric pressure without heating. The catalytic activity was almost unrelated to the crystal structure and the surface area of the alumina carrier.”

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Waseda University: “The activity of Ni/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] was quantitatively compared with that of Fe/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] and Ru/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] , which contained active metals for the conventional Haber-Bosch process. The activity sequence was Ni/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] > Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] > Fe/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] > no additive > Ru/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] , surprisingly indicating that the loading of Fe and Ru decreased the activity of Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ]. The catalytic activity of Ni/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] was dependent on the amount of loaded Ni, the calcination temperature, and the reaction time. XRD, visual, and XPS observations of the catalysts before the plasma reaction indicated the generation of NiO and NiAl [ [2] ] O [ [4] ] on Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] , the latter of which was generated upon high-temperature calcination. The NiO species was readily reduced to Ni metal in the plasma reaction, whereas the NiAl [ [2] ] O [ [4] ] species was difficult to reduce. The catalytic behavior could be attributed to the production of fine Ni metal particles that served as active sites.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “The P [ [N2] ] /P [ [H2] ] ratio dependence and rate constants of formation and decomposition of ammonia were finally determined for 5.0 wt % Ni/Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] calcined at 773 K. The ammonia yield was 6.3% at an applied voltage of 6.0 kV, a residence time of reactant gases of 0.12 min, and P [ [H2] ] /P [ [N2 ] ] = 1.”

For more information on this research see: Higher Activity of Ni/g-Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] over Fe/g-Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] and Ru/g-Al [ [2] ] O [ [3] ] for Catalytic Ammonia Synthesis in Nonthermal Atmospheric-Pressure Plasma of N [ [2] ] and H [ [2] ]. Catalysts, 2020,10(590):590. (Catalysts - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/catalysts). The publisher for Catalysts is MDPI AG.

A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/catal10050590.

Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Masakazu Iwamoto, Research Institute for Science and Engineering, Waseda University, 3-4-1 Okubo, Sinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169-8555, Japan. Additional authors for this research include Masataka Horikoshi, Ryu Hashimoto, Kaori Shimano, Tomiko Sawaguchi, Harunobu Teduka, Masahiko Matsukata.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
